column4: I have a drive that has one big partition that fills up the drive (ntfs). It has some data on it that I would like to save but I do not believe I can fit on my computer. Can the partition program in the live CD (The one you can use when you try Ubuntu) resize this so it is smaller so I can put linux on it? The drive is external and the data that is in the partition takes up a very small part...
would it be a problem if you lost this data?
Not a major problem. It is just downloaded programs.
It would take a long time to get them back though.
you can certainly resize it, a backup is highly recommended so you'll have to determine if you want to skip that step ;)
What are the probabilities of me permanently loosing my data?
low, still partitioning is one of the riskier operations
Well, I have redone the drive like 10 times. Never re sized though.
Ok, now after I resize and I put ubuntu in the free space that I have created, will windows just recognize the ntfs partition and use it like it is now?
it will, actually the ubuntu install will set up it's boot loader to be able to boot windows
Windows is on my internal drive
yes windows will only recognize the ntfs partition
it might suggest a disk check after resizing
Ok, because I had windows ignore the drive completely before an I couldnt even see it in the My comp. window.
Now when the chkdisk window or suggestion thing pops up, do I tell it not to?
what version ubuntu are you running?
